creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2017-07-20T16:01:56</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Ben Iceland (1910-1990) fought with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War.  In civilian life he found work as a social worker, farmer and, finally, as a high-school teacher of Latin.  Iceland was an active member of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (VALB) and edited VALB’s newsletter, <emph render="italic">the Volunteer</emph>, for eight years. This collection contains correspondence written while Iceland was in Spain and memoirs of his participation in the Spanish Civil War.  It also contains correspondence and subject files, most from the 1980s, related to VALB and the Volunteer.

p.value: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Iceland was an active member of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade (VALB).  In 1982 Manny Harriman, then retiring as editor of <emph render="italic">the Volunteer</emph>, VALB’s newsletter, tapped Iceland to become the next editor thus moving editorial functions of <emph render="italic">the Volunteer</emph> from the West Coast to the East.  Changing the location of <emph render="italic">the Volunteer's</emph> editorial board was only one of many VALB controversies over which Iceland would preside as editor.  Iceland served as editor of <emph render="italic">the Volunteer</emph> from 1982 until shortly before his death in 1990.

This collection contains Iceland's letters from Spain to Claire Brown Iceland, and several chapter-length typescript accounts of his Spanish Civil War experiences. Much of the collection consists of correspondence, articles, clippings, VALB reports and memos, and other materials related to Iceland's tenure as editor. The last box of the collection houses Iceland's unpublished translation of Virgil's Aeneid.

dsc.value:
Series I: Spanish Civil War Era, 1937-1940Scope and Content Note

This series consists of correspondence, mostly from Ben Iceland to his wife, Claire Brown Iceland; Iceland’s English-Spanish grammar book; photocopies of documents relating to Iceland’s time in Spain; and photocopied typescripts of Iceland’s memoirs of the Spanish Civil War.

BiographicalUndated11Iceland, Ben to Claire Brown Iceland193712Iceland, Ben to Claire Brown Iceland March-July 193813Iceland, Ben to Claire Brown Iceland August, 193814Iceland, Ben to Claire Brown Iceland September-October 193815Iceland, Ben to Rueben (Rubin) Iceland193816Lossowski, Vincent et al: “The Gypsy’s Curse” Undated17Postcard: photograph of last Americans leaving Spain Undated18Publication: “English-Spanish Grammar”193819Repatriation: ListDecember 1938110Sailing Announcement1937111Writings: “Alamansa”1939112Writings: “Anniversary”1940113Writings: “The Big Retreat” 1939114Writings: “Early Days in Spain”1939115Writings: “Last Months in Spain”Undated116Writings: “Teruel”1939117Writings: “A Train is Bombed”1939118Series II: Correspondence, 1976-1996Scope and Content Note

The bulk of the correspondence (1982-1990) is from fellow veterans of the Spanish Civil War, and is related to Iceland’s tenure as editor of the Volunteer. Many letters expand on controversies within VALB, or comment on articles and reviews published in the Volunteer. Subjects include contemporary issues such as the war in Nicaragua and proliferation of nuclear arms; the selection of material for the anthology, Our Fight, edited by Alvah Bessie and Albert Prago; as well as subjects related to the Spanish Civil War. Communism and Socialism were perennial sources of debate. Many letters include reminiscences of the war in Spain.

The correspondence includes letters from more than fifty different persons; Victor Berch, Alvah Bessie, Irving Weissman and Milton Wolff are among the more prolific correspondents. A 1990 letter from Carl Geiser provides a lengthy description of his trip to Cuba. Notable, too, is the correspondence from Wilhelm “Willi” Schutt, a 1929 German immigrant to New York City who fought with the Lincoln Battalion in Spain. Schutt, denied entry to the United States after the Spanish Civil War, lived in England during World War II. After the war he moved to East Germany where he lived until his death.

Most of the material in the subject files consists of documents related to VALB, on both the national and regional level, and the Volunteer. Correspondence, publicity material and documents about events commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Spanish Civil War are also well represented. Iceland’s full-length translation of Virgil’s Aeneid is included in the subject files.
